And shining as her Eyes: here's her Picture
Too in little.

div.stage: (Wildish steps a little aside, and looks upon it.)

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: O Impudence! his Sisters Picture, he forgot
He show'd me a month ago; this lock of
Hair, produc't so confidently, frighted me
A little, till I saw the colour.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.l: Gentlemen, I beg your pardon for pressing
Thus rudely into your Company; but the business
Concerns no less then all my Fortunes: I
Have been long a Suitor to a rich Widow, and have
At last prevail'd with her to marry me suddenly.

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: What is that to us, Sir?

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.l: Wildish, you'l I hope make my Excuse to
Your friends: coming into the Garden about
Half an hour ago, I lost a Bracelet of her
Hair, wrought with her own hands, so that
There is no deceiving her with a counterfeit:
A Waiter here tells me, he saw one of you
Take up such a thing.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Is this it?

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: That's mine, and compos'd of hair so dear
To me, that I would fight with Hector, the top
Of your order for least of 'um.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.l: And I with Hercules for mine: but
Pray Mr. Wildish, let me see it; if it be that I look:
For, no body will quarrel for 't, for't, for 'tis full
Of gray hairs, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Shall he see it?

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I'le make bold for once though.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.l: 'Tis my old Woman's.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: By the mark I'le swear, for 'tis as grizl'd
As a Silver-hair'd Rabbet; I may venture to
Let him have it, Estridge, I suppose, mayn't I?

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: Yes, yes, now I remember me, I sent mine
To have a new string put to it.

div.stage: Snappum goes off, Wildish follows him a little way.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Adieu, Snappum.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.l: Are any of these Gentlemen good Bubbles,
Mr. Wildish?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: What do I know, you had best ask 'um.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.l: No, I thank you, Sir, I can be satisfied
On easier terms; but you were always a Lover
Of ingenuity, pray tell me.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Away, away.
I'm sorry your Mistress has gray hairs so young,
I doubt you are not kind to her, Estridge.

sp.speaker: Mod.
sp.l: Nay, Wildish, don't insult upon a mistake.

div.stage: Estridge is out of Countenance, and looking up and down● sees the women in the next Arbour.

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: I think we have neighbours in the next
Arbour, and fine women they seem to
Be in their Masks.

sp.speaker: Mod.
sp.l: Let's entertain 'um— what Ladies, come a
Padding for Hearts here in your Vizards?
A pretty device to make a man in Love
With he can't tell who.

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: What, rob us of our Liberties without one
Word? not so much as stand and deliver?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.l: If we shou'd rob you of your Hearts,
Gentlemen, 'twere but petty Larceny; Victoria
And Olivia wou'd never send Hue and Cry after us.

sp.speaker: Mod.
sp.l: You know us, Madam.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.l: Yes, Gentlemen, somewhat better then
We did this morning, though I always
Suppos'd no less.

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: Then what?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.l: Then that you were the vainest Coxcombs
In the whole Town, Fellows that wou'd hate
A woman that were kind to you, because she
Takes from you the pleasure of belying her.

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: Olivia?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.l: The very same, Sir, whose Picture you have
In your Pocket, and about whose Hair you
Had like to have quarrell'd so manfully but now;
Who sends all the Town after you, and puts
Others off with slight Excuses; the obliging
Lady, whose health you drank by that name.

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: 'Twas another Olivia I meant, one
I knew abroad.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.l: And another Victoria that you meant, Modish?

sp.speaker: Mod.
sp.l: Right, right, my Landladies Daughter
At the Cheval d'Or, since gone into a Monastery.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.l: The Daughters of a French Everyoung,
I warrant too.

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: La Ieunesse was their Father, which is
All one with Everyoung in English.

sp.speaker: Mod.
sp.l: On our Honours, Ladies, we were ever most
Tender of your dear Credits, and are heartily
Sorry our Mistresses light to be of your names.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.l: Pray will you do me favour to let
Me see my Picture, I'm confident 'tis very
Like me.

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: Your French Name-sakes you mean, Madam;
That mal adroit Wildish let it fall and broke.
The Crystal, and I sent it just now away
To have a new one put to it, as I hope to be
Sav'd Madam.

sp.speaker: Mod.
sp.l: But, Madam, cou'd you think me so
Senseless, as discourse of you at that rate?
Here's Iack Wildish has heard us speak of
These Wenches a hundred times.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: 'Slight, these fellows
Will lye themselves into credit again, if
I han't a care of 'um instantly: Gentlemen
I understand no winks, the few lyes I'le
Venture upon I am resolv'd to keep for my
Own use.

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: Prithee Wildish help us but this once.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: No, no, go on, methinks you are in a
Very fair way; I am a stranger, the Ladies
Won't mind what I say.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.l: Yes, yes, we'll take your word.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Why then, Ladys, I assure you upon the Honour
Of a Gentleman, and by my friendship to those
Worthy persons I dare answer, they are too
Much Servants, to discourse so long of any
Thing but your selves: and for the French women
You know as much of 'um as I, having never
Heard title of 'um till this minute.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.l: You have brought a very● sufficient
Witness with you Gentlemen, we do
Believe him.

sp.speaker: Mod.
sp.l: Ours is not the first good cause has been lost
By ill Witnesses: but I perceive, Ladys, you
Don't know Iack Wildish, he 〈…〉
Droll in the whole Town; has a hundred
Of these fetches.

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: Pox on't, thou mayst bring all off yet.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Faith my 〈…〉
To deceive a Lady in a friends 〈◊〉,
To do it now, and in my own is all I can
Obtain of it.

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: 'S death, Sir

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Nay Estridge, 〈…〉
Mind it not, and 'tis uncivil 〈…〉
Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Mod.
sp.l: But that we are two to one, and scorn
Advantages, you shou'd not carry it off thus▪

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I shou'd be more 〈…〉
Three to one: but some other time for
These matters.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.l: Never blame Wildish, we were all the
While in the next Arbour, so that if he had
Taken your Cue never so readily, 't had done
You little service.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.l: Gentlemen this matter will bear no more
Raillery; we are sensible of our Honours, and
The injury your extravagant discourse might
Have done us, with any but so worthy a
Person as Mr. Wildish; but he we are
Confident understands himself too well
To have any ill thought of us from your
Vanity: we can do no less than forbid
You our House, and pray forbear it without
Further Ceremony.

div.stage: Wildish takes Victoria; Estridge offers to take Olivia, she refuses.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.l: No, Sir, you'le say I come to pick you up
In the Garden one time or other.

div.stage: Enter. Eugenio like an Officer, and three more▪

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Sir, there are some Souldiers below, say
They must search your House for some
Suspitious person.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.l: I warrant they mean Eugenio and Philander,
I am utterly undone, suspected for a Traytor,
And all long of those 〈…〉
Very glad I have got my Christian Cloth
On again: go and let 'um in.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: Sir, I hope you will excuse us, we do but
Follow our Orders, and● having search'd your
House for some dangerous persons 〈◊〉
Leave it you again in peace: 〈◊〉 and
Philander were your Sons, and therefore
Most probably judg'd to have made
Your House their Sanctuary.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.l: My House their Sanctuary! I had rather
It shou'd be their Grave: since they made
The State their Enemy, I have been so too.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: Then you have no thoughts of 'um for
Your Daughters?

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.l: No, Sir, I assure you: and to remove all doubt,
Althea's shortly to be marry'd to Horatio
(One that will bid you welcome, Sir, if you
Please to come to the wedding) and I hope to
Dispose of Diana e're long to some honest
Gentleman of our party.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.l: I command you, on my blessing, to answer
All things this Gentleman questions you
About, precisely, as it were my self.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: Sir, you do well, but you must retire
A little, whilst we examine your Daughters,
A man, though never so well meaning
Himself, can't answer for others.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: Lady, your Father here has shew'd
Himself a faithful Subject to the Common●
Wealth; it now remains to know what
Correspondence you entertain with Eugenio
And Philander, your former Servants.

sp.speaker: Alth.
sp.l: Upon my honour not the least, we are
Too strictly watch'd to have a correspondence
With any man, and are too careful of our
Selves to hold one with persons so obnoxio●●.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: Are you resolv'd you never will?

sp.speaker: Alth.
sp.l: As things are now they never shall.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: Must you then 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Alth.
sp.l: My Father tells me so, and I have 〈◊〉
Been Dutiful.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: Horatio's. an accomplish'd Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Alth.
sp.l: He is Sir, and worthy of more happiness
Than I can bring him to.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: By Heaven, she loves him.
You lov'd Eugenio once, and gave vow for vow.

sp.speaker: Alth.
sp.l: I did perhaps.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: A Stranger and an Enemy as he is I pity him.

sp.speaker: Alth.
sp.l: 'Tis noble in you, Sir, but we must all obey
Our Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: And curse 'um too, if they be all like mine,
That love where beauty, and not virtue, shine.
O that the Tyrants knew that I were here!
Death does more lovely now than life appear.
Since thou art false, 'tis she alone has charms;
Neglected love rests only in your arms:
When I am dead you may your choice a vow
Without reproach, which sure you cannot now:
And I shall want the sence of all my wrongs,
My death both to my rest, and thine belongs.

sp.speaker: Alth.
sp.l: Can this Eugenio be, and so unkind,
What strange Distemper rages in thy mind?
Cou'd once my Soul of a base thought allow,
He that believes me false shou'd find me so.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: Must you not, Madam, with Horatio wed?
'Tis a belief that your own words have bred.

sp.speaker: Alth.
sp.l: Forgive my fear, if any word of mine
Unto that hateful sound seem'd to encline:
Your rude appearance, of a Souldier, made
My tender heart, and very love afraid:
I durst not speak, what most I did believe,
But us'd such words as you wou'd best receive.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: Alas, Althea! what you told me here,
Did not create, although encrease, my fear:
That you must make him happy, is not new,
Nor did I learn the killing sounds from you;
The Streets are full of it; and every where
I can of nothing but this Hymen hear.

sp.speaker: Alth.
sp.l: 'Tis true, my Father does a match design
'Twixt me and this Horatio, and does joyn
Threats to Commands, urges th' uncertain state
Of your affairs, your Party, and the Fate
Of such as do a well form'd Power invade;
How they are always conquer'd or betray'd.
My Beauty fatal to it self the while
Inflames Horatio, and discourse (like Oyl)
Foments the fire: of such a Love he tells,
As would prevail but where your Image dwells;
But still in vain the Heart I gave to you,
The one does threaten, and the other woo.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: An absent Lover ill maintains the field:
Does not my Image to his presence yield?

sp.speaker: Alth.
sp.l: I'm sure it ought; reproaches so severe,
They that deserve 'um not will never bear.
'Twere just that Faith which you so ill deserve,
For one of nobler thoughts I shou'd reserve.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: We oft are made by a too great concern
(Like too much light) unable to discern.
The leave I gave to your surprise so late,
Now for my own distraction I intreat.
Where there is much of Love, there will appear
Mixt with our boldest hope some little fear.

sp.speaker: Alth.
sp.l: That fear in a true Lover soon wou'd dye,
Which to my Virtue is an Enemy.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: Hope is the passion of a calmer brest,
But high concernments are with doubt opprest.
To few, alas, is such assurance given
Not to fear Hell, although they hope for Heaven.
I not your Virtue, but my Fate accuse,
Which still does me with highest rigour use.

sp.speaker: Alth.
sp.l: Though Fate, Eugenio, for Misfortune meant,
I wou'd refuse to be the Instrument.
That dire necessity it seldom gave
Of harming them, whom we wou'd only save.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: But mark, I think I hear a noise of Swords.

sp.speaker: Alth.
sp.l: The sound, alas, no room for doubt affords.
You might perhaps be safe in your disguise.
Spoke within by Souldiers. Where are the rest of 'um?
Down with the doors there.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: Their sudden coming all such hope denies,
'Tis me they seek, I am betray'd; but yet
Since I can't shun, I'le try to break the net.
This Paper will inform your Sister where
She may of her unhappy Servant hear,
Make him remove, help him to shun that Fate
Which does for the unblest Eugenio wait.
My Rival in their head! by all the Gods,
Horatio, this is an unmanly odds;
Yet if on thee I can but fall reveng'd,
I life for death most happily have chang'd.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Eugenio. here! I thought of nothing less,
But my clear meaning this will best express.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: Down with 'um both.

div.stage: The Souldiers prevail, they are taken.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: Sir, let my life the cruel forfeit pay,
And bear not rashly so much worth away.
Horatio. was too far by Vertue led,
And sav'd that blood he nobly should have shed:
He being my Rival fear'd the world might say,
He for my hated life this train did lay.
Honour ingag'd his Sword in my defence,
And Honour is a kind of Innocence.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Eugenio. leave to intercede for me,
I only grieve I cou'd not rescue thee,
That so thou might'st thy preservation owe
To the same Vertue thou so ill didst know:
And I some fitter time might make thee owne
The injustice of thy mean aspersion,
To think I came thus rudely to invade
The place where all that I adore is laid;
And then to take my Rival in a snare,
Where if I wou'd I knew I cou'd not spare,
Was an affront thou with that life hadst paid,
Which I defended: but revenge shows base,
Which on our Honour more dependence has.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: Some other time for this dispute we'll take,
Revenge by threatning we the harder make.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: Come, Gentlemen, you must away, my
Orders press; you will have time enough to talk
Of these things in the Tower.

div.stage: Enter two Souldiers bringing in Sir Samuel.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: Sir, you must along.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.l: Who I! for what?

sp.speaker: Offic.
sp.l: For harbouring Eugenio here, a known
Enemy to the State.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.l: You brought him with you for ought I know,
I n'er saw his face, I answer'd an Officer, and
Two Souldiers that came to search for him
Even now, and as I thought, gave 'um satisfaction.
But when I heard the clashing of Swords, because
I wou'd not be made accessory to any thing that
Might happen, I confess I retir'd into a
Corner of my Garret.

sp.speaker: Offic.
sp.l: Sir, this won't satisfie, the Receiver is as
Bad as the Thief; I have found a Traytor
In your house, and you shall answer it.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.l: Eugenio, you are an honest Gentleman,
Pray speak, did I know any thing of your
Being here?

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: Not in the least, Sir: but my word I fear
Will do you little service.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: What, Sir Samuel, agen under persecution?
Nay, faith, I can do you no service now, these
Are a sort of Gamesters I dare not meddle withal.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.l: I am undone! here's Eugenio found in my
House, and they are carrying him to the Tower.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Come, bear up, Sir, if there come a turn,
You'l be a great man.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.l: I shall be hang'd on that side, and to speak
My own Conscience, I have deserv'd it.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: No, to lye in Prison for concealing Cavaliers,
Will be great merit; and let me tell you as a friend,
There's like to be a turn suddenly, 'tis thought the
General will declare like an honest man, I say
No more; therefore carry your self moderately,
This accident may chance to do you good service,
If you have the grace to make the right use on't:
But how came Eugenio and Horatio of a side?

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.l: I came but just now among 'um, and know
Nothing; but 'tis a strange thing a man can't be
Believ'd in his own defence: carry me to Prison?
I'le see what Justices hand they have for't.

sp.speaker: Offic.
sp.l: We shall find hands enough, ne're fear it.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'TIs strange I nothing of Eugenio hear,
So long an absence may be worth a fear:
His friendship was not wont to hide from me
Of his most secret thoughts the new Decree.
I doubt his Love impatient of delay,
Has to Althea found some desperate way,
His passion cou'd not my slow cure attend,
On which, alas, he did in vain depend.
I was to blame, no sooner to provide
Against deluded hope's unruly tide;
Which now I fear has born him on a shelf,
Where he'll unkindly perish by himself.
Ha! a strange face! wou'd I had not been seen;
But 'tis too good for Treason to lurk in.
Sure Gentle youth the place you have mistook,
I cannot be the man for whom you look.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Philander in your troubled face I read
Some apprehensions that you are betray'd:
But when you shall my woful story hear,
A Juster sorrow will remove your fear.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thou hast my name, and yet I know thee not,
Quickly unty sweet youth this painful knot.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Know you this hand?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Alas it is my own,
This from Eugenio cou'd be had or none:
Speak, is he dead? is this his Legacy?
And has he sent it, gentle youth, by thee?
Has he Horatio fought? killing, or slain,
He almost equally wou'd breed my pain.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: He and Horatio fought, but on a side.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What wonder beyond this can Fate provide.
I knew, Eugenio, thou wert always brave,
And that thy Love was still thy Honours slave.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: On your friends part you have the vertue brought,
But 'twas Horatio for Eugenio fought.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Such a prodigious union cou'd not fail.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: A Band of Souldiers did o're both prevail.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Is my unhappy friend a Prisoner made?

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: He is, and close in the White Tower laid:
He bad me tell you so, that you might shun
The desperate hazard that his life must run.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How came he, gentle youth, thus to expose
My life to one whom he so little knows?

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: I am his near Relation, and have been
Privy to all Designs he has been in.
He bids you to remove without delay,
For y'are endanger'd hourly by your stay:
The Souldiers about him a Paper took,
Which, though obscurely, of your Lodging spoke.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: In vain we to that wretch good counsel give,
Resolv'd to perish, and unfit to live:
When he is gone, what business have I here?
What can again be worth a hope or fear?
The hour he dyes this shall be my relief,
If I cou'd need another wound than grief.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: How can you hope to please Eugenio's Ghost,
In killing him whom he esteems the most?
In life our friends we chuse, but those we hate
We rather wish Companions of our Fate:
If I a present to his shade wou'd send,
It shou'd be of his Foe, and not his Friend.
But yet I hope Eugenio may escape;
Safety has come in an unlookt for shape.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: That hope alone makes me consent to live.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Can you for life no other reason give▪

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: None that, alas! is fit for thee to hear.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Does then Diana's heart so vile appear?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I hope thou wilt my better Genius prove,
Since thus thou know'st my business and my love.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: She tells me you have often fill'd her Ears
With gentle words, and wet her arms with tears;
Vow'd that your hope and fear, grief, and delight,
Her frowns or favours only cou'd excite.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why so I did, sweet youth, and told her true,
But I'm amaz'd it shou'd be known by you.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Of late she has worn a face of discontent,
That seem'd neglected friendship to lament:
Eugenio. to her Sister found a way,
Though various hazards in his passage lay.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Unwisely he the short-liv'd pleasure sought,
Too soon 'twas paid for, and too dearly bought▪
Like Orpheus for one poor untimely look,
He has the hope of all he lov'd forsook.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: That haste exprest a passion, though to blame:
Impatience is of love the best extream.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: That Heir's accurs'd, that for a present sum
Resigns the hope of all he has to come.
I would Diana to the world prefer,
And for her venture any thing but her.
But, gentle youth, methinks thou speak'st as though
Thou mad'st a doubt, whether I lov'd or no.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Pray Heaven Diana mayn't: your fault was great,
To think of Honour when the day was set
For Hymens Rites; when nought else could destroy
Your hopes, which then were ripening into joy,
You were a Traytor to the State declar'd,
And in the glittering toyls of Fate ensnar'd.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Be witness Heaven, and all ye Powers above,
That see our infant passions weakly move,
E're they have force into the face to climb,
Or to one action can our wills encline,
If ever, for one moment, in my breast
I gave to any (she inspir'd not) rest.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Why did you then such daring projects frame,
And danger court that not concern'd your flame?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Tis true, before I knew Diana's charms,
I courted Fame in danger and in Arms,
And thought no Cause cou'd lasting glory bring,
Like the just quarrel of our injur'd King.
Eugenio's friendship too that Fire improv'd,
And made me wed that Cause I ever lov'd:
What since I did was on a former score,
My Fate she can't condemn, but must deplore.
I was in honour pre-engag'd too far,
E're to retire, and yet to merit her.
But whence could'st thou this hated knowledge gain?
He worse than kills, who makes me live in pain:
Thy Beauty, Youth, and Words do all perswade,
Thou happy in her neerest trust art made.
sp.stage: Diana here drops a Ring, pulling out a Handkerchief.
sp.l: Ye Gods! the Ring I to Diana sent!
Do not frail man beyond his Nature tempt.
The good thou hast done, I thus forget it all,
And let my vengeance on my Rival fall.
Draw, or I'le leave thee dead upon the ground.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: I dare not draw— and sure you dare not wound.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: With sudden light I for a while am blind,
I sought a Rival, and a Mistress find;
Where I thought all my rage, my love is due,
So high a pitch my wishes never flew;
I am not by degrees to pleasure led,
Nor slowly made the doubtful steps to tread,
But in an instant, my exalted mind
Feels all her hopes set free, and fears confin'd:
So Kings in Battels that they gave for gone,
Redeem their own and win another Crown.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: That Faith, which nothing shou'd in question bring,
From a few words you doubt, and from a Ring:
How can I hope a lasting friendship, where
So light appearance brings so mean a fear?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Such a surprize a jealous pang might give
To any breast where so much love does live.
But why, Diana, in this strange disguise?
Was it to make me happier by surprise?

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Cou'd I my fear, as well as love o'recome,
You'd been preserv'd, and never known by whom;
Such a concern I wou'd not have betray'd,
Till I were surer of your passion made.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What accident ill understood, cou'd prove
Of that dire force to make you doubt my love?
You needs must know how we were all betray'd,
And the hard scape I and Eugenio made;
And since, it had been fatal to be seen,
So that this Chamber my whole world has been.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: What made me doubt, it matters not to know,
Let it suffice I do no longer so.
The dreadful Sword, which at my breast you held,
Though with much fear, I with more joy beheld:
For he that truly does his Rival hate,
Declares he loves his Mistress at that rate.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Look on thy self, and measure thence my love,
Think what a flame so bright a form must move:
That Knot be confident will ever last,
Which Passion ty'd, and Reason has made fast.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Farewel, Philander, think on what I've said,
And kindly judge the weakness of a Maid.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thou art too cruel in so short a stay;
Thus would I gaze my very sight away.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Though for your safety nothing was too dear,
Now give me leave for my own self to fear.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: She has appear'd like Lightning to my sight,
Which when 'tis vanisht, leaves a darker night.

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: 'Twas certainly that Rogue Wildish that betray'd
Us; the Arbour and Bottle of Wine, were his motions.

sp.speaker: Mod.
sp.l: Without all peradventure, you saw the
Ladies, when they threw us off, took him home
With 'um, nothing could be plainer— what think
You if one of us fought him?

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: Why, faith I think we had e'en as good let
That alone; hang him, he'll fight; 'twas only
A trick he put upon us, and let's rall it off,
And serve him in his own kind.

sp.speaker: Mod.
sp.l: As how?

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: Do you remember a certain Cousin of his
That Everyoung carry'd us to, the Widow of
A rich Alderman, who dy'd suddenly, and left her
All he had? this Widow he intends for Sir Samuel
Forecast, and I make no question but he is to have
A round Sum for his good word.
What think you now, if I order it, that one
Of us marry this Widow, then I hope
We are sufficiently reveng'd?

sp.speaker: Mod.
sp.l: But how is't possible?

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: Nothing so easie: her Maid has promis'd me
To perswade her to take a walk in the Mulberry▪
Garden; this is a time there is little or no
Company there, 'tis but waiting at the door
With a trusty 〈…〉
Force her whither 〈…〉
Her own accord she'll 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Mod.
sp.l: Why so?

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: If for no other, for the same reason that th●●
Eat Horse-flesh in a Siege; because she can come
At nothing else.

sp.speaker: Mod.
sp.l: If it were a foolish Girl, we might do
Somewhat with her indeed; but these Widows
Are like old Birds not to be tam'd she'll fight and
Scratch, and fly about, there will be no enduring her.

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: Fear nothing: when she considers she has no
Other way to save her Reputation, she'll hear reason.

sp.speaker: Mod.
sp.l: Well; but being equal Adventurers, how
Shall we agree about the Prize?

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: He that marries her, shall give the other a
Statute upon his Estate, for two thousand
Pounds, a pretty good Sum, and will serve to stop a gap.

sp.speaker: Mod.
sp.l: Content, and I wish thee joy of her
With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: You shall find me as good a Pay-master
As her Husband the old Alderman wou'd
Have been: but stand close, here she comes.

div.stage: Enter the Widow and her Maid, they 〈◊〉 'um.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Thieves, Murderers, Villains what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: Nothing, nothing, but lie make bold to stop
That pretty mouth of thine, Widow, for once.

sp.speaker: Mod.
sp.l: Whither shall we carry 'um?

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: To a little house I have taken a quarter of
A mile off for that purpose, where no body
Could hear 'um, though they had Falconers
Or Huntsmens voices.

div.stage: Enter Sir. John Everyoung, and Sir Samuel Forecast.

sp.speaker: Ever.
sp.l: Give you joy, Brother, give you joy.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Ever.
sp.l: Why, of your Lieutenancy, of the Tower
Know you can be here upon no other 〈◊〉 and
Indeed your fidelity to the 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.l: Sir, give you joy of your new suit, and
Fair Perriwig there.

sp.speaker: Ever.
sp.l: Faith, Brother, it site with no Fortune
To day, what are's the matter, I was never
Worse put together in all my life, and but to
Congratulate your advancement, wou'd not
Have left the Company I din'd with.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.l: I hope to return your kind Visit in the Fleet,
And see your Daughters sell Ale and Cakes there,
And your Worship with fewer Trappings on;
For thither your extravagant Courses point.

sp.speaker: Ever.
sp.l: May my Petriwig never know a good day,
Nor be taken for my own half again,
But come off always with my Hat, if it
Cost me above twelve pounds.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.l: Pox on your Hat, and your Perriwig, can you
Tell how I shall get out?

sp.speaker: Ever.
sp.l: No more then how you got in; but you are
Wise, and know business: alas, I know nothing
But how to sort Ribands, make Horse-matches,
Throw away my money at Dice, and keep my
Self out of the Tower.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.l: O my ungracious Girls!

sp.speaker: Ever.
sp.l: What of them? have they broke prison,
And taken Sanctuary in the Arms of some sturdy
Prentice, Fencing-master, Brother of the Blade,
Or any other inferior Rascat? you were
So strict to 'um, I never look'd for other.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.l: Not so fast; but if you can be serious for
A minute, do: they are vertuous, but Eugenio
A former Servant to Althea, since declar'd
A Traytor to the State, was taken in my house;
I suspected to have been privy to his being
There, and so carried along with him hither:
I protested my Innocence to the Officers, urg'd
My former Service, but all would nor do.

sp.speaker: Ever.
sp.l: S'light of hope you had more wit, this is
The happiest accident that ever 〈…〉
For an old notorious, Round-head to be taken
For a Cavalier at this time; why I never
Thought it had been in you, this was a Stratagem
Might have become Machewile himself▪

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.l: Why, what's the matter? all's well I hope.

sp.speaker: Ever.
sp.l: Yes, never better, the General has this day to
Some persons of quality declar'd for the King;
All Cavaliers are immediately to have their
Liberty; therefore make haste to reconcile
With Eugenio and Philander: I have an order
For the delivery of all such Prisoners as are
Here upon the account of Loyalty to their Prince.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.l: Philander and Eugenio, on my Daughters
Account, will do me all the service they can, and I
Hope to make some advantage of this imprisonment,

sp.speaker: Ever.
sp.l: I'le go and release Eugenio, and bring him
To you; Horatio is discharg'd already: though,
We fall out now and then about trifles, we are
Brothers, and ought to serve one another
In matters of concern.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: You see now, Ladies, what Fellows you cast
Your good opinions on: if I said any thing
That was disrespectful to either of you,
It ought to go for nothing, I was meerly
Your decoy in the business.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.l: We are very well satisfi'd on all hands.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.l: Sure they'l never have the impudence
To trouble us agen.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.l: Now wou'd I were married to Estridge,
That I might plague him soundly.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: How can you make that a Plague, Madam?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.l: A hundred ways: I wou'd never come
Home till three a clock in the morning;
Tumble my own Handkercher my self, to make
Him jealous; break his soundest sleeps in
Commendation of his bosom-friend, and never
Leave till I have made 'um quarrel; fold up
All manner of Papers, like Love-Letters,
And burn 'um just as he comes into th' Room.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I can tell you how to be reveng'd on him
Beyond all this.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.l: Prithee how, Wildish?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Why, marry me, make a good Wife to me,
And let him hang himself for rage.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.l: I am not so inveterate an Enemy, I'le forgive
Him rather: if I were your Wife, I must board
Half a year with a Friend in the Country, tumble
About the other half in most villainous Hackneys,
Lye two pair of Stairs high, and wear black
Farrendine the whole year about; see you when
You had no Money to play, and then be kist out
Of a Ring or a Bracelet.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I wou'd not use a City Widow of five and fifty so,
With seven small Children: and am I to suffer
Nothing all this while?

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.l: What can you suffer?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Why, the loss of that which is dearer than life,
My liberty; be known for a marry'd man, and so
Put my self out of all capacity, of breaking Gold,
Promising marriage, or any other way of
Ensuring my self to scrupulous young Virgins
I shall like hereafter.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.l: That is to be taken from the occasion of
Playing the Rascal: is that all?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Not half; if I make but love to a Chamber-maid,
I shall be answer'd, you have a sweet Lady of your
Own, and why will you wrong her? if I get
Acquainted with any young woman, after the fourth
Or fifth visit, be look'd upon by her Father and Mother,
Worse than the Tax-Gatherers in a Country Village;
All this you count nothing.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.l: Not to a Lover, Wildish,

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Well, there is no service so desperate,
That a gallant man will shrink at, if he like
His reward; and to give his hand thus to a woman,
In him that rightly understands what he does,
Is as bold an action as Mutius 〈◊〉: yet
That I may use it hereafter where and when I please,
Upon my dear Olivia I'le venture it.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.l: Softly, when you please, and where I please.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Content Madam: will you do us the favour to
Be a Witness?

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.l: Well Mr. Wildish I'le dance bare-foot
To serve you.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.l: Hold, hold Wildish, my heart fails me.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: Slight, I had a qualm too, there's certainly
A more than ordinary providence attends me;
I shall scape yet, I am now in a twitter,
Like a Gamester upon a great by, that is
Heartily afraid he shall lose it, and yet his
Love to the money won't suffer him to draw
Stakes. I must have her.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.l: Nay, now you are come thus far, e'ne go on,

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.l: Well, Wildish, give me thy hand; the first
Time thou anger'st me, I'le have a Gallant;
And the next, make thee a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Madam, you know your Father does command.
That you shou'd shortly give me your fair hand
Before a Priest; but since find no part
Goes along with it of your generous heart,
My mind the charming present can refuse,
Fearing t'indulge a passion you accuse;
My joy with your least trouble weigh'd must still
Appear, to my own self the greater ill.

sp.speaker: Alth.
sp.l: Such words as these, Horatio, but heap more
Upon a debt that was too great before;
I'm cover'd with confusion when I weigh
How much I owe, how little I can pay:
You may with ease a fairer Mistress find,
And with more ease such worth will make her kind;
And if I e're that happy Virgin know,
I'le sue to make her pay you what I owe.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: To change your thoughts, I will no longer try,
But with the stream I cannot turn, comply
I to Victoria will my suit renew,
And hope to find an Advocate in you.

sp.speaker: Alth.
sp.l: You may command me, and Victoria's mind
Is of it self to you too well inclin'd.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: All this methinks shou'd your belief perswade,
I no contrivance with those Villains had,
To take my Rival in so mean a way,
But only came their sudden rage to stay:
All that confusion, and surprize cou'd do,
My passion made me apprehend for you.

sp.speaker: Alth.
sp.l: Horatio's Honour does too brightly shine,
To be accus'd of such a low design;
Had you within the bounds of friendship staid,
Your self and me you had both happy made.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: With ease from friendship we to love are led,
That slipery path who can securely tread?

div.stage: Enter Sir. Samuel Forecast, Sir John Everyoung, and Eugenio.

sp.speaker: Alth.
sp.l: I see my Father, and Eugenio here,
And in all faces sudden joys appear.

div.stage: Forecast, Everyoung, and Horatio seem to discourse.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: Fortune, I pardon thee thy short-liv'd spite,
I for thy constant temper took a fit,
Th'art kind, and gentle, and 'tis we are blind,
Who do mistrust the ways thou hast design'd
To make us blest, though better than our own.

sp.speaker: Alth.
sp.l: Can you have joy, and yet Althea none▪

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: May I all misery first undergo,
E're joy divided from Althea know.

sp.speaker: Alth.
sp.l: What is this wonder hangs upon thy tongue
Delay does only to ill news belong.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: Madam, your Father licenses my flame,
And you alone can now oppose my claim;
That Cause which Armys did in vain support,
And noblest spirits did, successless, court
We in a bloodless triumph shining see,
Without the dire effects of Victory.
For in the Generals breast (the noblest Scene)
The Fate of England has transacted been:
On Albion's Throne he will our Monarch place,
Our Neighbours terrour, and our Nations grace,
Whilst at his blest approach, all factious minds
Vanish, like leaves before Autumnal Winds.

sp.speaker: Alth.
sp.l: Such truth in love and loyalty y'ave shown,
What less for both cou'd by just Heaven be done?

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: This happiness, though great, yet is not all,
My dearest friend I soon shall Brother call;
Diana must his deathless Flame repay.

sp.speaker: Alth.
sp.l: Fate, to be pardon'd, had no other way.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: See how your Father kindly strives to evade
His former promise to Horatio made.

sp.speaker: Alth.
sp.l: That work's so nobly in his breast begun,
That a few words will finish what's undone:
Horatio. does all happiness despise,
From my obedience, which my love denies.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.l: Horatio has releas'd me of my promise to him,
And seeing your changeless love to one another,
Was resolv'd to have mov'd it to me, if I had
Not prevented him.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: Such honour, noble youth, I must confess,
Gives wonder equal to my happiness.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Althea. I resign, my guilty flame
Was too unjust to reach so fair an aim:
Victoria's. wrongs did my success oppose,
And my lost passion its own penance grows.
So some Offenders are their duty taught
By th'ill effect and nature of their fault.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: My apprehensions by these words are clear'd.
And I dare love that Virtue which I fear'd.
In love alone this mystery we find,
Men best agree when of a different mind.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: There now remains but one thing more to do,
'Tis that Philander may be sent for too.
But see he comes.

sp.speaker: Fore.
sp.l: Brother, if your Daughter were here, we
Might have a Dance.
Sir, you are heartily welcome, I kept my Girl
Safe for you, she has not been so much as blown
Upon since you saw her; I knew honest men
Wou'd not be always kept from their own,
There wou'd come a time.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sir, I was ever most oblig'd to you—
Eugenio here! then I am doubly blest,
And only fear to be with joy opprest.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: The joys of Friendship well prepare our mind
For the high raptures we in love shall find:
The name of Brothers we shall soon obtain.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Friendship so perfect by no name can gain.
Fate is at length asham'd, or weary grown
Upon a Flame you smil'd so long, to frown;
As Vessels tost upon the raging Main,
With greater joy the wisht-for Port obtain;
Our love this short, fierce tempest having past,
Will joys more high, since less expected, tast.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: But in the Storm did you throw nothing out?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Wrong not my love with so unkind a doubt.

sp.speaker: Ever.
sp.l: Wildish, thou'rt an honest fellow, I'm glad
I found thee.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Sir, the honest fellow desires to be known to
You by another name, having newly marry'd your
Daughter Olivia.

sp.speaker: Ever.
sp.l: When, pray Mr. Wildish?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Just now, Sir, the words are scarce out of our Mouths.

sp.speaker: Ever.
sp.l: Well, this is a day I could not have been angry
If thou hadst got her with Child upon a Contract;
But you might have ask'd my leave, e're you
Went about to make me a Grandfather.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: If I had had a good Jointure to offer, so I
Wou'd, but if I do make you a Grandfather,
'Tis not done maliciously, I'le swear.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: My guilty Cause my self I dare not plead,
But beg your innocence will intercede:
Since all my fault your matchless beauty made,
Your goodness now shou'd my excuse perswade.

sp.speaker: Alth.
sp.l: I in Victoria will my int'rest try,
You, and me both, she hardly shall deny.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Victoria's. mind I cannot hope to move,
Unless a Parents power assist my love;
Her duty will not your commands withstand,
She'll take a worthless Servant from your hand.

sp.speaker: Ever.
sp.l: I'm sure she can have no exception to so
Deserving a person as Horatio; Lovers, like Spaniels, do
But show their mettal in a little ranging: though you
Had a twittering to Althea, you'le make ne're the
Worse Husband to Victoria. Victoria!

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.l: Sir, what's your pleasure?

sp.speaker: Ever.
sp.l: That which will prove yours in the end: I
Charge you upon my blessing, give Horatio your
Hand, go and be marry'd with your Cousins,
And make but one work of it.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.l: Sir, I am all obedience: who e're strove
At once against her duty, and her lover.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: But Estridge, what fine Lady have you got there

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: A certain Widow which I have cast my
Self away upon: a Kinswoman of yours, Wildish,
That you formerly design'd for the Right Worshipful
Sir, Formal there: do you know her now?—
Sir we made bold with her without your consent.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Old acquaintance, I saith, how is't? I have made
As bold, and been as welcome too, as e're you'le be
Sir: but why did you steal a marriage thus?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: You know I always lov'd stoln pleasures, but
This marriage stole me; your old Knight was
Uncertain, came on by inches, this Gentleman
Leapt into the matter, forc'd me into a Coach, and
Marry'd me in an instant: I cou'd have been
Content to have been a Lady, that I might have
Taken place of my Mistress when she comes to Town.
But a Bird in the hand—.

sp.speaker: Estr.
sp.l: Why, have you a Mistress?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: As sure as you have had a hundred,
And now have a Wife.

sp.speaker: Mod.
sp.l: I doubt as things go, I shall scarce find you
As good a Pay-master as the old Alderman.

div.stage: Estridge pulls his hand from her, and looks angry.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Nay, never use her ill now, 'twas none of her
Fault, she is a very good Creature, and one
That I plac't to personate my Cousin, on purpose
To catch Sir Samuel Forecast; you know he
Took the forfeiture of a Mortgage that concern'd
A very good Friend of mine, and I was resolv'd to
Be reveng'd of him; if you will needs run your
Head into the Noose that's prepar'd for another,
Who can help it? my Cousin is married in Ireland,
Whither she went last Summer to look after
Some money, due to her last Husband.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I am her House-keeper though, and can bid
You welcome till she returns.

sp.speaker: Oliv.
sp.l: A pretty pert thing, I like her humour, she
Carries it off well: but Wildish, you shall visit
Her no more now we are married.

div.stage: Wild Fear not, Estridge will take order for that. Horatio to Victoria.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: How I do hate my self! that could so long
At once such Beauty and such Goodness wrong.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.l: My kindness has forgot you were to blame,
You guilt consum'd in your reviving flame.

sp.speaker: Ever.
sp.l: Now you are all pair'd, let's have a Dance.

div.stage: After the Dance, a great shout within.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: I hear the peoples voice in joyful crys,
Like conquering Troops o're flying Enemies;
They seem to teach us in a ruder way
The Honour due to this all-healing day.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Let's part a while, and vye who shall express
The highest sense of this great happiness.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: POets of all men have the hardest Game,
Their best Endeavours can no Favours claim.
The Lawyer, if o'rethrown, though by the Laws,
He quits himself, and lays it on your Cause.
The Souldier is esteem'd a Man of War,
And Honour gains, if he but bravely dare.
The grave Physitian, if his Patient dye,
He shakes his head, and blames Mortality.
Only poor Poets their own faults must bear,
Therefore grave Iudges be not too severe:
Our Author humbly hopes to scape your Rage,
Being no known Offender on the Stage,
He came by chance, is a meer Traveller;
All Countries Civil unto Strangers are:
Yet faith he's arm'd how e're your Censures go,
And can prevent the harm, though not the blow.
No Poet can from this one Comfort fall,
The best ne're pleas'd, nor worst displeas'd you all.
